channel.title: philstar.com - RSS Headlines
channel.description: Philippine News for the Filipino Global Community

item.title: ‘Remember Recto Bank sinking’
item.author: Michael Punongbayan
item.description: A year after the ramming and sinking of a Filipino fishing boat by a Chinese vessel in Recto Bank, former foreign affairs chief Albert del Rosario is urging Filipinos not to forget the incident or surrender to China’s “persistent” aggression to gain control of the entire South China Sea.

item.title: ‘No revenue sources, no stimulus package’
item.author: Alexis Romero
item.description: There can be no stimulus package without revenue sources, Malacañang said yesterday, after the House of Representatives passed a bill that seeks to allot P1.3 trillion to jumpstart the economy battered by the coronavirus disease 2019 pandemic.

item.title: Return to stricter quarantine possible – Palace
item.author: Alexis Romero
item.description: Quarantine measures in Metro Manila may be tightened anew if the number of persons infected with coronavirus disease 2019 increases, Malacañang said yesterday.

item.title: Poverty rate seen to rise this year
item.author: Czeriza Valencia
item.description: More Filipinos will be plunged into poverty this year even as government cash transfers and wage subsidies attempt to blunt the effects of the economic fallout from the coronavirus disease 2019 pandemic on the most vulnerable, according to the World Bank.

item.title: Teachers seek P1,000 internet allowance
item.author: Janvic Mateo
item.description: Teachers should be provided with internet or communication allowance to cover expenses related to the shift to distance learning in the upcoming school year, an organization said.

item.title: 3,700 cases of violence vs women, children recorded during ECQ
item.author: Sheila Crisostomo
item.description: Nearly 3,700 violent incidents against women and children have been recorded while the country is under quarantine because of the coronavirus disease 2019 pandemic, according to President Duterte.

item.title: June 12 ‘mañanita’ protest: Only 10 allowed
item.author: Christina Mendez
item.description: Groups opposing the Anti-Terrorism Act, which now awaits President Duterte’s signature, are planning protests they call “mañanita” to mark Independence Day on June 12.

item.title: PAGCOR eyes gradual reopening of casinos
item.author: Mary Grace Padin
item.description: The Philippine Amusement and Gaming Corp. is eyeing the resumption of casino operations this month to save the jobs of thousands of workers employed by the gaming industry and generate much-needed revenues for the government’s coronavirus disease 2019 response.

item.title: Congress submits anti-terror bill to Duterte
item.author: Christina Mendez
item.description: The new anti-terrorism bill is now ready for President Duterte’s signature, as Congress yesterday transmitted to Malacañang copies of the controversial measure that various groups and sectors are opposing.

item.title: Duterte: More than 15,000 trained as COVID-19 contact tracers
item.author: Alexis Romero
item.description: The DOH previously said about P11.7 billion is needed to hire 136,000 contact tracers for at least three months.
